SafetyInspectionBy: Texas Municipal League Intergovernmental Risk Pool

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
AQUILLA WATER SUPPLY DISTRICT

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Aquilla Water Supply District is a wholesale potable water production and treatment facility located in Hill County, Texas.
The treatment plant rated capacity is six million gallons of treated water per day.  Currently, daily production averages between two and three million gallons per day.  Primary water disinfection is accomplished by the use of chlorine, which is stored in one-ton cylinders and is subject to the EPA Risk Management Program.  No more than two chlorine cylinders are in use at any time.
Storage and handling of the chlorine is permitted at this facility only by experienced operators properly trained to do so.  Two operators minimum are always required to be present when handling chlorine cylinders.  In the twenty years that this facility has been in operation, no hazardous release of chlorine gas has occurred that had any off-site impact.

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO
Based on EPA worst-case scenario (2,000 lb. discharge in ten minutes, three miles to toxic endpoint), the rural area in which the treatment plant is located, and prevailing wind patterns, up to twenty five individuals could be affected.  The Hill County Sheriff's Office, which serves as the coordinator for the Local Emergency Planning Committee, will be notified and Chemtrec (800-424-9300) will also be called.  District personnel will coordinate with the LEPC and Chemtrec to take appropriate actions necessary to ensure the safety of individuals in the affected area.

ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO
If a non-catastrophic release should occur (leaking valve, etc.) notification will still be made as in the worst-case scenario; however, active mitigation measures will also be taken to reduce outside exposure.  This will include, but not be limited to, water spray at the source of the discharge area as a way to convert the gas release to a less hazardous solution.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Evaluation of the current program is ongoing.  Change
s will be made to the current program as improvements are made.
